titlestmt.titleproper: Waco Public Library Association records, Inclusive: 1856-1925, undated, Bulk: 1898-1921, undated

note.p: © 2021 The Texas Collection. All rights reserved.

profiledesc.creation: Finding Aid was generated by The Texas Collection staff, using the STAR Knowledge Center for Archives (SKCA) task that automatically creates EAD files from the Archive's SKCA catalog records.

did.head: Records Summary
did.abstract: The Waco Public Library Association records trace the formation and continuing operations of the first Waco Public Library, funded in part by Andrew Carnegie.

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: The Waco Public Library Association records trace the formation and continuing operations of the first Waco Public Library, funded in part by philanthropist Andrew Carnegie. The Waco Public Library Association was formed on 1898 May 4, intending to furnish Waco with its first public library. In 1899, using circulars, benefits, and other means of raising financial support, the Association founded a library of 600 books in a rented cottage at 116 North Eighth Street. The library officially opened to the public on 1900 January 22.

The library soon grew out of its small home, however, and the Association wrote to Andrew Carnegie for potential financial backing. Carnegie, who eventually built 32 such libraries in Texas, agreed to donate $30,000 if a site and $3,000 of yearly support could be obtained from the City of Waco. The city government agreed, and a Building Committee with local businessman William Herman Hoffman Sr. at its head was formed. The new Carnegie Library, with some 3,200 books, opened in Waco on 1904 November 28. Although the original Carnegie building was eventually demolished, the Waco Public Library system remains strong today; its board is now called the Waco-McLennan County Library Advisory Commission. The Waco Public Library Association Records will prove to be an excellent research for anyone interested in the history of Waco, Progressive Era philanthropy, Carnegie Libraries, or the development of a public library from the ground up.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The Waco Public Library Association records consist of correspondence, legal documents, financial materials, scrapbooks, and literary productions related to the Waco Public Library Association. Of particular note is a set of correspondence seeking funding from Andrew Carnegie to found the first Waco Public Library building.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Prior to this finding aid, the Waco Public Library Association records were organized into folders by material type. Some folder titles have been preserved.
Currently, the collection is organized into five series: I. Correspondence, II. Legal Documents, III. Financial Materials, IV. Scrapbook, and V. Literary Productions.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: All requests for copying of materials must be submitted to The Texas Collection in writing. Please use the Request Form for Copying Materials sheet. Unpublished materials authored or otherwise produced by the creator (s) of this collection are in the public domain. There are no restrictions on use. Copyright status for other collection materials is unknown. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.

userestrict.head: Use/Re-use Restrictions
userestrict.p: The collection is open for research.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Waco Public Library Association records, Accession #2041, Box #, Folder #, The Texas Collection, Baylor University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Described by Adina Johnson. Released on 2014-07-17.

relatedmaterial.head: Related references

relatedmaterial.bibref: “Library Has Colorful History.” Waco Citizen, 1981 August 29.

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: This series contains correspondence regarding fundraising for the Waco Public Library, including communication with other Carnegie libraries. Also included are mailing lists of potential supporters and donors.

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: This series contains legal documents regarding the new Waco Public Library including business and architectural contracts.

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: This series contains financial materials related to the fundraising associated with the development of a new library.

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: This series contains a scrapbook of press clippings related to the Waco library.

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: This series includes reports, membership lists, clippings, circulars, and other printed materials related to the Waco Public Library Association.
